title: Postsynthetic Paddle-Wheel Cross-Linking and Functionalization of 1,3-Phenylenebis(azanetriyl)tetrabenzoate-Based MOFs
abstract: enzoate)), was prepared by a solvothermal reaction in a mixture of DMF and EtOH. Postsynthetic modification of DUT-71 using different neutral nitrogen-containing bridging molecules in a single-crystal to single-crystal transformation fashion results in a series of porous compounds (DUT-72, DUT-73a, DUT-73b, DUT-74, DUT-90, DUT-91, and DUT-95) with apparent BET surface area up to 2700 m

. Interestingly, the Cu–Cu distances between paddle wheels during the transformation are adapted to the bridging ligands, demonstrating the flexible character of DUT-71. After solvent removal and resolvation, a drastic color change from green to dark blue and vice versa was observed. This observation was studied in detail

by monitoring the adsorption of ethanol in the low-concentration region by UV/vis analysis. The correlation between the ethanol adsorption uptake and the intensity of the characteristic absorption peaks in the UV/vis spectra renders the new materials promising candidates for vapochromic sensing.
text: Metal–organic frameworks are modular materials that are assembled from molecular building units in modular fashion and therefore can achieve a high degree of well-defined functionality. This makes them very attractive for many applications where porosity

Further features of this material class are, e.g., (i) crystallinity, which enables controlled design and targeted modification of the framework based on the crystallographic information, and (ii) optical functions, due to the presence of transition or rare earth metals.

The optical response can be caused by the coordinating molecules, which do not participate in formation of the network and can be removed or introduced without changes in the integrity of the framework. The solvatochromic/vapochromic properties makes MOFs interesting for use in sensing applications.

The main envisioned application of vapochromic materials is as an indicator in sensors to detect volatile organic compounds in a variety of environments, including industrial, domestic, and medical areas.
The nature of the origin of solvochromism/vaporchromism in MOFs can be different: charge transfer influenced by solvent polarity,
changes in the coordination sphere of the metal ion due to solvent removal,
or changes in the coordination sphere induced by ligand exchange.

Since the accurate detection of substances at low parts-per-million levels is a significant challenge, the porosity of the MOF system combined with the response of classical transition metal complexes can drastically enhance detection sensitivity.
Thus, to efficiently sense vapors, a robust porous MOF system is necessary.

Often, highly porous MOFs involve long linker molecules and form open frameworks (void fraction up to 95%) that may collapse during solvent removal. Although the most important factors influencing the robustness of the MOFs during activation are not completely understood so far, it is widely accepted that significant capillary forces, and hence surface tension, can be created during activation, which, in turn, can yield fully or partially collapsed frameworks.
Thus, supercritical drying is especially important for mesoporous MOFs.

are factors that influence the robustness of the framework during the activation procedure. One useful approach to stabilize the framework against collapse is the pillaring of paddle-wheel clusters in MOFs.

Both the stabilization and functionalization of the MOF can result from exposing the parent MOF crystals to a concentrated solution of the (functional) linker of choice in a carefully selected solvent.
In 2004, Kitagawa and co-workers, followed by Chen and co-workers, performed a series of experiments linking 2D paddle-wheel layers with bipyridyl pillars to obtain 3D structures.
Pillared paddle-wheel MOFs have been often utilized as model systems to control pore dimensions and surface functionality.
One impressive illustration of the strengthening of a framework was reported by Klein et al.
DUT-34, a very fragile framework with
topology that could not be desolvated while retaining its porosity, even by supercritical CO
drying, was stabilized by incorporation of a neutral nitrogen-containing cross-linker. After supercritical drying, a material (DUT-23) with permanent porosity and a remarkable surface area of 4850 m
The group of Suh inserted a linear nitrogen-containing ligand postsynthetically into SNU-30, a MOF based on a tetracarboxylic linker.
In the presence of excess DEF, the framework was able to release the pillar in a single-crystal to single-crystal reaction.
Recently, Hupp and co-workers showed that the nitrogen-containing linker incorporated into the pillared-layer structure could be replaced by a longer one, with the parent’s topology retained.

In this article, we demonstrate that the postsynthetic cross-linking of paddle wheels in a single-crystal to single-crystal fashion leads to a significant stability increase in three-dimensional 1,3-phenylenebis(azanetriyl)tetrabenzoate (
pbatb)-based MOFs, resulting in a series of vapochromic sensing materials. Using the new MOF Cu

pbatb) (named DUT-71) as a starting material, several stabilizing N-donor ligands with various lengths were introduced into the framework. The crystal structures, solvent removal conditions, and porosity of all modified compounds were studied. All derivative materials show different robustness during solvent removal as well as different gas and vapor adsorption properties.

A two-necked round-bottomed flask was charged with palladium acetate (83 mg, 0.317 mmol, 4 mol %), 2,2′-bis(diphenylphosphino)-1,1′-binaphthyl (BINAP, 461 mg, 0.74 mmol, 8 mol %), and cesium carbonate (18.08 g, 55.48 mmol, 6 equiv) and filled with argon. Ethyl 4-bromobenzoate (10.55 g, 46.236 mmol, 5 equiv, 7.55 mL) dissolved in dioxane (25 mL) was added, and the mixture was heated at 100 °C. After 20 min, 1,3-phenylendiamine (1 g, 9.25 mmol) dissolved in dioxane (30 mL) was added. The reaction was stopped after 7 days (TLC control), and the cooled mixture was filtered over a Celite frit. The filter cake was washed with THF. The solvent was evaporated, and a mixture of diethyl ether and pentane was added. The solvents were evaporated again, and the solid crude product was washed with a diethyl ether/pentane mixture and finally with small amounts of ethanol (Yield: 4.785 g, 74%).

In a round-bottomed flask, tetraethyl-4,4′,4″,4‴-(1,3-phenylenebis(azanetriyl))tetrabenzoate (2.7 g, 3.96 mmol) was dissolved in THF (55 mL); to this solution was added potassium hydroxide (4.44 g, 79 mmol, 20 equiv) in water (27 mL), and the mixture was heated at 70 °C for 20 h. After cooling to room temperature, the organic phase was evaporated and the aqueous phase was acidified with 6 M HCl. The precipitate was filtered and washed with water, small amounts of ethanol, and diethyl ether. The product was dried overnight in vacuum (2.24 g, 96%).
For a typical synthesis of DUT-71, H

pbatb (100 mg, 0.17 mmol) and copper(II)chloride dihydrate (86 mg, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF and ethanol (1:1, 20 mL) in a Pyrex tube using an ultrasonic bath. The solution was heated in an oven at 80 °C for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent was replaced with a fresh mixture of DMF and ethanol (1:1).

To the washed DUT-71 crystals was added 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco, 114 mg, 1.02 mmol) dissolved in a mixture of DMF and ethanol (1:1, 6 mL), and the mixture was heated at 80 °C for 7 days. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent was replaced with a fresh mixture of DMF and ethanol (1:1).
Yield: based on DUT-71. Anal. Calcd (%) for Cu

-imidazol-1-yl)benzene (1,3-bib, 71 mg, 0.34 mmol) dissolved in a mixture of DMF and ethanol (1:1, 6 mL), and the mixture was heated at 80 °C for 7 days. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent was replaced with a fresh mixture of DMF and ethanol (1:1).
Yield: based on DUT-71. Anal. Calcd (%) for Cu

Yield: based on DUT-71. Anal. Calcd (%) for Cu

After cooling to room temperature, the solvent was replaced with a fresh mixture of DMF and ethanol (1:1).
Yield: based on DUT-71. Anal. Calcd (%) for Cu

For a typical experiment, ca. 9 mg of supercritically dried MOF material (for more details, see the

) was mixed with 150 mg of KBr in a glovebox. The mixture was transferred into a sample holder equipped with a dome to prevent the contact with the ambient atmosphere. The sample holder was connected with the equipment for dynamic vapor dosing. Nitrogen was used as the carrier gas. The total flow was 100 mL min
Tetratopic linkers are very promising building blocks in MOF chemistry, giving a plethora of highly porous and functional materials.

) leads to the formation of green rod-like crystals of Cu
. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that the compound crystallizes in tetragonal space group
. The crystal structure contains two symmetry-independent Cu paddle-wheel units. Their centers of gravity are located in the 4

.. for Cu3—Cu3) Wyckoff positions, correspondingly. The interconnection of these square-planar inorganic building blocks by tetratopic ligands in a tetrahedral conformation results in a trinodal 4,4,4-connected 3D framework with
Figure 1. Linker molecules used for the synthesis and postsynthetic modification of DUT-71.
Such a framework configuration leads to the formation of two types of cages (Figure
d): a larger one of 20.6 × 9.4 Å and a smaller cage of 25.5 × 3.7 Å. All distances are measured from atom center to atom center without considering the Van der Waals radii of the atoms.
In accordance with a PLATON report, the structure of DUT-71 contains a solvent-accessible void of 14629.9 Å
Moreover, Poreblazer 3.0 software suggests a theoretical accessible surface area of 4712 m
, a total pore volume of 1.56 cm
, and a limiting pore diameter of 6 Å.

Such outstanding calculated textural properties motivated us to determine the porosity experimentally. Unfortunately, solvent exchange to ethanol or dichloromethane with further application of dynamic vacuum at room temperature resulted in amorphous material that is not accessible to nitrogen at −196 °C. Also, the supercritical carbon dioxide activation procedure did not result in a porous material, demonstrating the high fragility of the framework.
Since the paddle-wheel units in the structure were aligned along the
axis, we decided, inspired by our previous work,
to stabilize the structure of DUT-71 by insertion of neutral diamine cross-linkers of appropriate length between the neighboring paddle wheels.

Detailed analysis of the crystal structure of DUT-71 results in two different spacing distances between Cu2-Cu2 and Cu1-Cu1 atoms from neighboring paddle wheels along the [001] direction, which could be used for hypothetical cross-linker integration: 13.84(1) Å (large gap) and 8.00(1) Å (small gap) (Figures
). Insertion of pillars into one or both gaps should strengthen the framework in the
direction. One suitable molecule for incorporation into a short gap could be 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco), which has 2.58 Å between nitrogen atoms.
Figure 2. Views on the structure of DUT-71: (a) along the
axis. (d) Distance between copper paddle wheels in the direction of c. Light blue, Cu; dark blue, N; red, O; gray, C. Red and yellow spheres indicate the pore volume.
Indeed, soaking DUT-71 crystals in a solution of dabco in DMF/ethanol leads to the incorporation of dabco into the network, resulting in a new compound with the framework composition Cu
The small gaps in DUT-72 are occupied by dabco molecules, connecting two neighboring paddle wheels along the

direction. All other paddle wheels are coordinated by dabco in a monodentate manner. Interestingly, the framework adapts itself to the cross-linker, and, as result, the corresponding Cu–Cu distance decreases from 8.00(1) Å in DUT-71 to 7.02(1) Å in DUT-72. Such changes lead to an increase of the large gap from 13.84(1) to 14.65(1) Å.

The crystals of DUT-71 were soaked in a solution of the corresponding cross-linker at elevated temperature. The successful incorporation of the 1,3-bib cross-linker into the large gap of DUT-71 could be demonstrated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Interestingly, the incorporation of the 1,4-bib into the DUT-71 framework is accompanied by a slight distortion of the 4
paddle wheels from the 4-fold axis. This leads to a reduction of the space group symmetry from
(DUT-73b). Since the simplest group–subgroup relation between these two space groups,

Unfortunately, none of these postsynthetic modifications of DUT-71 by cross-linking of only one gap type lead to sufficient robustness. Obviously, the framework is too soft, and strengthening only the large or small spacing is not sufficient to achieve a porous solvent-free framework. Therefore, crystals of DUT-73a, DUT-73b, and DUT-74 were subjected to a further postsynthetic modification step to introduce additional dabco linkers to interconnect the small gaps (Figure

This resulted in a series of novel materials with ideal compositions: Cu

). It is of note that the orthorhombic DUT-73b phase converts again to the tetragonal phase (DUT-91) after dabco insertion.

for DUT-90, DUT-91, and DUT-95, respectively. Obviously, not all paddle wheels are occupied by dabco molecules after the second postsynthetic modification step (

The durability of cross-linker insertion was proven for DUT-95. In contrast to the results of Suh and co-workers on SNU-30, where the embedding of the postsynthetic bpta linker is reversible, DUT-95 shows no leaching of bpta or dabco after soaking the sample for 5 days in DEF. The supernatant solution was monitored by
H NMR and showed no signals for bpta and dabco molecules.
After solvent exchange to acetone and drying using supercritical CO
, the PXRD patterns of DUT-91 and DUT-95 do not change, demonstrating the framework’s stability (
). Interestingly, the PXRD pattern of activated DUT-90 contains only

0 reflections, indicating a leak of long-range order in the [001] direction. Obviously, in contrast to DUT-91 and DUT-95 that contain a linear cross-linker, the bent 1,3-bib ligand could not provide the necessary degree of robustness to the framework in the desolvated state. After resolvation with a fresh mixture of DMF and ethanol (1:1), all reflections in the PXRD pattern reappear, indicating recovery of the long-range order after resolvation.

Interestingly, activation/resolvation of the DUT-90, DUT-91, and DUT-95 materials was accompanied by a color change from green (for the as-made or solvent-exchanged materials) to blue (after activation) and vice versa (Figure

). Therefore, the compounds can be potentially used as vapochromic sensors. Since the sensing of alcohol vapor, especially ethanol, is of wide interest, the behavior of the materials in the presence of ethanol was investigated.
Figure 5. Color change of activated (left) to solvated DUT-95 (right).
The interaction between the frameworks of DUT-90, DUT-91, and DUT-95 and ethanol was studied by solid-state UV/vis spectroscopy.

Since all DUT samples investigated in this study undergo a significant color change during resolvation, the changes observed in their UV/vis spectra were expected after exposure to ethanol. In order to study the kinetics of ethanol vapor adsorption on DUT-90 (Figures

Thus, DUT-90, DUT-91, and DUT-95 can be considered to be promising materials for sensing and for estimation of ethanol vapor concentrations in the parts-per-million region, where detection is based on color change.
Figure 8. Correlation between ethanol physisorption measurement (red graph) and 1/absorbance at 566 nm from UV/vis experiments (black graph) in DUT-90 (top) and DUT-95 (bottom) at 298 K.

A series of new copper paddle-wheel-containing MOFs based on a tetratopic carboxylate linker molecule was obtained using solvothermal synthesis and postsynthetic functionalization. The flexible starting compound, DUT-71, was permanently functionalized by coordinating different nitrogen-containing, neutral ligands. Such interconnection increases the rigidity of the framework drastically and generates a permanent porosity accessible to gas molecules. The pillared MOFs show a color change from green to blue during the drying process and from blue to green by exposure to ethanol vapor. The color change was followed in situ by UV/vis spectroscopy during the ethanol physisorption experiments. The intensity of the absorbance peak at 566 nm was correlated with ethanol concentration, rendering these materials promising candidates for sensing applications at ethanol concentrations from 50 to 600 ppm.
Synthetic procedures, PXRD patterns, physisorption data, TG analysis data, UV/vis data, and crystallographic data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at

He, Yabing; Zhou, Wei; Qian, Guodong; Chen, Banglin

Natural gas (NG), whose main component is methane, is an attractive fuel for vehicular applications.  Realization of safe, cheap and convenient means and materials for high-capacity methane storage can significantly facilitate the implementation of natural gas fuelled vehicles.  The physisorption based process involving porous materials offers an efficient storage methodol. and the emerging porous metal-org. frameworks have been explored as potential candidates because of their extraordinarily high porosities, tunable pore/cage sizes and easily immobilized functional sites.  In this view, we provide an overview of the current status of metal-org. frameworks for methane storage.
There is no corresponding record for this reference.

Applications of metal-organic frameworks in heterogeneous supramolecular catalysis
Liu, Jiewei; Chen, Lianfen; Cui, Hao; Zhang, Jianyong; Zhang, Li; Su, Cheng-Yong

A review.  This review summarizes the use of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) as a versatile supramol. platform to develop heterogeneous catalysts for a variety of org. reactions, esp. for liq.-phase reactions.  Following a background introduction about catalytic relevance to various metal-org. materials, crystal engineering of MOFs, characterization and evaluation methods of MOF catalysis, the authors categorize catalytic MOFs based on the types of active sites, including coordinatively unsatd. metal sites (CUMs), metallo-ligands, functional org. sites (FOS), as well as metal nanoparticles (MNPs) embedded in the cavities.  The authors emphasize the incidental or deliberate formation of active sites, the stability, heterogeneity, and shape/size selectivity for MOF catalysis.  Finally, the authors briefly introduce their relevance into photo- and biomimetic catalysis, and compare MOFs with other typical porous solids such as zeolites and mesoporous silica with regard to their different attributes, and provide a view on future trends and developments in MOF-based catalysis.
Adsorptive separation on metal-organic frameworks in the liquid phase
Van de Voorde, Ben; Bueken, Bart; Denayer, Joeri; De Vos, Dirk

While much attention of the MOF community has been devoted to adsorption and purifn. of gases, there is now also a vast body of data on the capability of MOFs to sep. and purify liq. mixts.  Initial studies focused on sepn. of petrochems. in apolar backgrounds, but the attention has moved now to the sepn. of complex, e.g. chiral compds., and to the isolation of biobased compds. from aq. media.  We here give an overview of most of the existing literature, with an accent on sepn. mechanisms and structure-selectivity relationships.
A Luminescent Microporous Metal-Organic Framework for the Recognition and Sensing of Anions
Chen, Banglin; Wang, Liangbo; Zapata, Fatima; Qian, Guodong; Lobkovsky, Emil B.
Journal of the American Chemical Society
A luminescent microporous metal-org. framework Tb(BTC)G was developed for the recognition and sensing of anions, exhibiting a high-sensitivity sensing function with respect to fluoride.
Optical metal-organic framework sensor for selective discrimination of some toxic metal ions in water
Shahat, Ahmed; Hassan, Hassan M. A.; Azzazy, Hassan M. E.

This paper reports the development of a facile and effective approach, based on the use of Zr-based metal-org. frameworks (UiO-66) sensor with micropores geometry, shape and particle morphol. for the visual detection and removal of ultra-traces of some toxic metal ions such as Bi(III), Zn(II), Pb(II), Hg(II) and Cd(II).  UiO-66 was used as selective carriers for accommodating hydrophobic chromophore probes such as dithizone (DZ) without coupling agent for sensitive and selective discrimination of trace level of toxic analytes.  The developed UiO-66 sensor was utilized for the detection of ultra-traces of some toxic metal ions with the naked eye.  The new sensor displays high sensitivity and selectivity of a wide range of detectable metals analytes up to 10-10 mol dm-3 in soln., in a rapid analyte uptake response (seconds).  The developed sensor is stable, cost effective, easy to prep., and would be useful for rapid detection and removal of ultra-traces of toxic metal ions in water samples.
Design and sensing applications of metal-organic framework composites
Lei, Jianping; Qian, Ruocan; Ling, Pinghua; Cui, Lin; Ju, Huangxian

As cryst. mol. materials, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have unique chem. and phys. properties, such as ultrahigh porosity, tunable structure, and high thermal and chem. stability.  These characteristics make MOFs suitable for use in gas storage, sepn., catalysis, biomedical imaging and sensing.  Precise chem. modifications can esp. endow MOFs with specific functions and offer the possibility of designing a new generation of sensing devices.  This article focuses on the design of functional MOFs and signal-transduction strategy, including optical, electrochem., mech., and photoelectrochem. schemes, for anal. applications in detection of solvent mols., metal ions, DNA, proteins, and other important biomols.
There is no corresponding record for this reference.
Solvatochromic Behavior of a Nanotubular Metal-Organic Framework for Sensing Small Molecules
Lu, Zhen-Zhong; Zhang, Rui; Li, Yi-Zhi; Guo, Zi-Jian; Zheng, He-Gen
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A nanotubular metal-org. framework (MOF), {[(WS4Cu4)I2(dptz)3]·DMF}n (dptz = 3,6-di(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine, DMF = DMF) for sensing small solvent mols. is presented.  When accommodating different solvent mols. as guests, the resulting inclusion compds. exhibit different colors depending on the solvent guests, and more interestingly, the band gaps of these solvent-included complexes are in linear correlation with the polarity of the guest solvents.  The solvent mols. can be sensed by the changes of UV-visible spectra of the corresponding inclusion compds., showing a new way of signal transduction as a new kind of sensor.  The sensing by such a MOF occurs within the channel-contg. material rather than on the external surface.
There is no corresponding record for this reference.
Cyano-Bridged Re6Q8 (Q = S, Se) Cluster-Cobalt(II) Framework Materials: Versatile Solid Chemical Sensors
Beauvais, Laurance G.; Shores, Matthew P.; Long, Jeffrey R.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Face-capped octahedral clusters [Re6Q8(CN)6]4- (Q = S, Se) were used to space apart partially hydrated Co2+ ions in extended solid frameworks, creating porous materials that display dramatic color changes upon exposure to certain org. solvents.  The clusters react with cobaltous ions in aq. soln. to ppt. the new solid phases [Co2(H2O)4][Re6S8(CN)6]·10H2O (1), Cs2[Co(H2O)2][Re6S8(CN)6]·2H2O (2), and [Co(H2O)3]4[Co2(H2O)4][Re6Se8(CN)6]3·44H2O (3).  The structures of 1·2H2O and 3 were detd. by single-crystal x-ray anal.  The former consists of an expanded Prussian blue type framework with [Re6S8]2+ and [Co2(μ-OH2)2]4+ cluster cores occupying alternate metal ion sites, and features cubelike cages enclosing water-filled cavities ∼258 Å3 in vol.  The latter structure exhibits a network of Co2+ ions and [Co2(μ-OH2)2]4+ cores connected through [Re6Se8(CN)6]4- clusters, defining an array of 1-dimensional channels with min. internal diams. of 4.8 Å.  A Rietveld refinement against x-ray powder diffraction data established compd. 2 as isostructural to an analogous Fe-contg. phase with a two-dimensional framework reminiscent of the Hoffman clathrates.  Thermogravimetric analyses show that all three compds. are fully dehydrated by ∼100°, with no further significant loss of mass <500°.  Upon exposure to di-Et ether vapor, the color of compds. 1 and 3 immediately changes from orange to an intense blue-violet or blue; other polar solvents induce somewhat different colors.  These (reversible) changes are assocd. with the emergence of an envelope of new absorption features at wavelengths between 500 and 650 nm, and the magnitude of the response to a solvent can be estd. by measuring the relative intensity of a band with a max. near 600 nm.  The authors propose that the vapochromic response is due to solvent mols. entering the pores of the solid, where they disrupt the hydrogen-bonded water network, prompting the release of bound water from the [Co2(H2O)4]4+ clusters and conversion of their Co centers from octahedral to tetrahedral coordination.  Significantly, this process does not destroy the three-dimensional connectivity in either structure, but rather creates a much more flexible framework that can expand to accommodate the incoming solvent mols.  Spectroscopic and magnetic data confirm the change in coordination geometry, and the trends in solvent responses (e.g., methanol < ethanol < n-propanol < i-propanol) are consistent with a decreased ability to support the bridging water ligands of the clusters as steric bulk increases.  Size-selective sensing is demonstrated with Me t-Bu ether, which causes a color change in compd. 3, but not in compd. 1.  X-ray powder diffraction expts. indicate that the vapochromic response in both compds. is affiliated with a reversible change in the bulk crystal structure of the material.  Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility data for compd. 1 suggest a weak antiferromagnetic coupling interaction between the water-bridged Co2+ ions of the dinuclear cluster units.  Finally, a simple chem. sensing device employing these solids is described, along with some properties relevant to its function.
A Chromo-Fluorogenic Tetrazole-Based CoBr2 Coordination Polymer Gel as a Highly Sensitive and Selective Chemosensor for Volatile Gases Containing Chloride
Lee, Hyejin; Jung, Sung Ho; Han, Won Seok; Moon, Jong Hun; Kang, Sunwoo; Lee, Jin Yong; Jung, Jong Hwa; Shinkai, Seiji

A tetrazole-based ligand without long alkyl chains is used to form a coordination polymer gel with CoBr2 (1).  Gel 1 has a spherical structure with a 20-30 nm diam.  More interestingly, gel 1 selectively recognizes toxic gases, such as HCl, SOCl2, (COCl)2, and COCl2 that contain chloride atoms.
Solvents control over the degree of interpenetration in metal-organic frameworks and their high sensitivities for detecting nitrobenzene at ppm level

Solvothermal syntheses in DMF and acetonitrile afforded two novel MOFs, Zn3(L1)2(L2)·3.6 DMF·4.0 H2O (1) and Zn3(L1)2(L2) (2) [L1 = 4-[3-(4-carboxyphenoxy)-2-[(4-carboxyphenoxy)methyl]-2-methyl-propoxy]benzoate, L2 = 1,4-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene], resp.  Single crystal x-ray analyses reveal that 1 and 2 are structurally closely related with the same building blocks and 3-dimensional 3,8-connected tfz-d net.  1 Is based on a 2-fold interpenetrating network with extra-framework DMF and water mols. located in the void space, while 2 is different in its 3-fold interpenetrating network and absence of any solvent mols.  This simple and easy strategy unprecedentedly controls the degree of interpenetration in MOFs through varying solvents.  Luminescent properties of activated phase 1' and 2 well dispersed in different solvents have also been investigated systematically, which demonstrate distinct solvent-dependent luminescent spectra with emission intensities significantly quenched toward nitrobenzene (NB).  For luminescence responses of 1' and 2 dispersed in DMF soln. with gradually increased NB contents, detectable quenching effects were obsd. even at a very low NB concn. of 50 ppm, indicating extremely high sensitivities of 1' and 2 towards NB.
Analyte Detection with Cu-BTC Metal-Organic Framework Thin Films by Means of Mass-Sensitive and Work-Function-Based Readout
Davydovskaya, Polina; Ranft, Annekatrin; Lotsch, Bettina V.; Pohle, Roland

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) constitute a new generation of porous cryst. materials, which have recently come into focus as analyte-specific active elements in thin-film sensor devices.  Cu-BTC-also known as HKUST-1-is one of the most theor. and exptl. studied members of the MOF family.  Its capability to selectively adsorb different gas mols. renders this material a promising candidate for applications in chem. gas and vapor sensing.  Here, the authors explore details of the host-guest interactions between HKUST-1 and various analytes under different environmental conditions and study the vapor adsorption mechanism by mass-sensitive and work-function-based readouts.  These complementary transduction mechanisms were successfully applied for the detection of low ppm (2 to 50 ppm) concns. of different alcs. (methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol) adsorbed into Cu-BTC thin films.  Evaluation of the results allows for the comparison of the amts. of adsorbed vapors and the contribution of each vapor to the changes of the electronic properties of Cu-BTC.  The influence of the length of the alc. chain (C1-C3) and geometry (1-propanol, 2-propanol) as well as their polarity on the sensing performance was studied, revealing that in dry air, short chain alcs. are more likely adsorbed than long chain alcs., whereas in humid air, this preference is changed, and the sensitivity toward alcs. is generally decreased.  The adsorption mechanism is revealed to differ for dry and humid atms., changing from a site-specific binding of alcs. to the open metal sites under dry conditions to weak physisorption of the analytes dissolved in surface-adsorbed water reservoirs in humid air, with the signal strength being governed by their relative concn.
Mondloch, Joseph E.; Karagiaridi, Olga; Farha, Omar K.; Hupp, Joseph T.

Cryst. metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a highly desirable class of solid-state materials.  Some of their most attractive features include exceptionally high porosities as well as surface areas.  A key aspect to the realization of high porosity is the removal of guest mols. from the framework while still maintaining its structural integrity (i.e., "activation").  This contribution highlights the strategies utilized to date for activating MOFs, including: (i) conventional heating and vacuum; (ii) solvent-exchange; (iii) supercrit. CO2 (scCO2) exchange; (iv) freeze-drying; and (v) chem. treatment.
A new metal-organic framework with ultra-high surface area
Gruenker, Ronny; Bon, Volodymyr; Mueller, Philipp; Stoeck, Ulrich; Krause, Simon; Mueller, Uwe; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan

A new mesoporous MOF, Zn4O(bpdc)(btctb)4/3 (DUT-32), contg. linear ditopic (bpdc2-; 4,4'-biphenylenedicarboxylic acid) and tritopic (btctb3-; 4,4',4''-[benzene-1,3,5-triyltris(carbonylimino)]tris-benzoate) linkers, was synthesized.  The highly porous solid has a total pore vol. of 3.16 cm3 g-1 and a specific BET surface area of 6411 m2 g-1, adding this compd. to the top ten porous materials with the highest BET surface area.
Zeolitic Imidazolate Framework as Formaldehyde Gas Sensor
Chen, Er-Xia; Yang, Hui; Zhang, Jian

Traditional semiconducting metal oxide-based gas sensors are always limited on low surface areas and high operating temps.  Considering the high surface area and high stability of zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF), ZIF-67 (surface area of 1832.2 m2 g-1) was 1st employed as a promising formaldehyde gas sensor at a low operating temp. (150°), and the gas sensor could detect formaldehyde ≥5 ppm.  This work develops a new promising application approach for porous metal-org. frameworks.
Stabilization of Metal-Organic Frameworks with High Surface Areas by the Incorporation of Mesocavities with Microwindows
Zhao, Dan; Yuan, Daqiang; Sun, Daofeng; Zhou, Hong-Cai
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Reactions between two novel hexatopic carboxylate ligands and copper salts give rise to two isostructural metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with a (3,24)-connected network topol. contg. both micro- and mesocavities with sizes of up to 3 nm.  The formulas of the complexes are [Zn(H2O)]3(btei)·9DMF·5H2O, [Cu(H2O)]3(btei)·5DMF·4H2O and [Cu(H2O)]3(ntei)·21DMA·10H2O (H6btei = 5,5',5''-benzene-1,3,5-triyltris(1-ethynyl-2-isophthalic acid), H6ntei = hexaethyl 5,5',5''-(4,4',4''-nitrilotris(benzene-4,1-diyl)tris(ethyne-2,1-diyl))triisophthalic acid).  Both frameworks retain their porosity after guest-mol. removal, leading to high surface areas.  Constructing MOFs contg. mesocavities with microwindows may serve as a general approach toward stable MOFs with high surface areas.
A highly porous metal-organic framework, constructed from a cuboctahedral super-molecular building block, with exceptionally high methane uptake
Stoeck, Ulrich; Krause, Simon; Bon, Volodymyr; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan

A highly porous metal-org. framework Cu2(BBCDC) (BBCDC = 9,9'-([1,1'-biphenyl]-4,4'-diyl)bis(9H-carbazole-3,6-dicarboxylate)) (DUT-49) with a sp. surface area of 5476 m2 g-1, a pore vol. of 2.91 cm3 g-1, a H2 excess uptake of 80 mg g-1 (77 K, 50 bar), a CO2 excess uptake of 2.01 g g-1 (298 K, 50 bar) and an exceptionally high excess methane storage capacity of 308 mg g-1 (298 K, 110 bar) was obtained using an extended tetratopic linker.
A coordinatively linked Yb metal-organic framework demonstrates high thermal stability and uncommon gas-adsorption selectivity
Ma, Shengqian; Wang, Xi-Sen; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai

The Yb metal-org. framework PCN-17 Yb4(μ4-OH2)L8/3(SO4)2·3H2O·10DMSO (L = 4,4',4''-S-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoate), which contains coordinatively (through SO42- ions) linked, doubly interpenetrated (8,3)-nets, is stable up to 480° and exhibits selective adsorption of H2 and O2 over N2 and CO.
Microporous Lanthanide Metal-Organic Frameworks Containing Coordinatively Linked Interpenetration: Syntheses, Gas Adsorption Studies, Thermal Stability Analysis, and Photoluminescence Investigation
Ma, Shengqian; Yuan, Daqiang; Wang, Xi-Sen; Zhou, Hong-Cai

Under solvothermal conditions, the reactions of trigonal-planar ligand, TATB (4,4',4''-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyl-tribenzoate) with Dy(NO3)3, Er(NO3)3, Y(NO3)3, Yb(NO3)3, gave rise to four microporous lanthanide metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), designated as PCN-17 (Dy), PCN-17 (Er), PCN-17 (Y), and PCN-17 (Yb), resp.  The four porous MOFs are isostructural, with their crystal unit parameters shrinking in the order of PCN-17 (Dy), PCN-17 (Y), PCN-17 (Er), and PCN-17 (Yb), which also reflects the lanthanides' contraction trend.  All of them adopt the novel square-planar Ln4(μ4-H2O) cluster as the secondary building unit and contain coordinatively linked doubly interpenetrated (8,3)-connected nets.  In addn. to exhibiting interesting photoluminescence phenomena, the coordinatively linked interpenetration restricts the pore sizes and affords them selective adsorption of H2 and O2 over N2 and CO, as well as renders them with high thermal stability of 500-550° as demonstrated from TGA profiles.
Tuning MOF Stability and Porosity via Adding Rigid Pillars
Tan, Yan-Xi; He, Yan-Ping; Zhang, Jian

High stability and permanent porosity are the premise of general applicability for metal-org. framework materials (MOFs).  By varying degrees of success on increasing the connectivity of the linear pillar 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy), two isostructural flexible frameworks [M2(obb)2(DMF)2]·2DMF (1, M = Zn or Cu; H2obb = 4,4'-oxybis(benzoic acid), DMF = DMF) with no gas sorption are structurally modified into two rigid frameworks [Zn2(obb)2(bpy)]·DMF (2) and [Cu2(obb)2(bpy)0.5(DMF)]·2DMF (3) with notable gas sorption and sepn. properties.  Esp. for 3, it exhibits gas selective uptake for the adsorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4 under 273 K and has an interesting phys. lock effect in benzene and cyclohexane sorption.  The results provide a successful strategy on tuning framework stability of flexible structures via adding rigid pillars.
Stitching 2D Polymeric Layers into Flexible Interpenetrated Metal-Organic Frameworks within Single Crystals
Zhang, Zi-Xuan; Ding, Ni-Ni; Zhang, Wen-Hua; Chen, Jin-Xiang; Young, David J.; Hor, T. S. Andy

A 2D coordination polymer, [Cd3(BTB)2(DEF)4]·DEF (H3BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoic acid), prepd. with bulky diethylformamide solvates exhibits channels which allow dipyridyl bridging ligands to diffuse into the crystal lattice.  The absorbed dipyridyls thread through the pores of one layer and substitute the surface diethylformamide mols. on the neighboring layers to stitch alternate layers to form flexible interpenetrated metal-org. frameworks.  The threading process also results in exchange of the bulky diethylformamide solvates for aqua to minimize congestion and, more strikingly, forces the slippage of two-dimensional layers, while still maintaining crystallinity.
Tuning the structure and function of metal-organic frameworks via linker design
Lu, Weigang; Wei, Zhangwen; Gu, Zhi-Yuan; Liu, Tian-Fu; Park, Jinhee; Park, Jihye; Tian, Jian; Zhang, Muwei; Zhang, Qiang; Gentle III, Thomas; Bosch, Mathieu; Zhou, Hong-Cai

A review.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are constructed from metal ions/clusters coordinated by org. linkers (or bridging-ligands).  The hallmark of MOFs is their permanent porosity, which is frequently found in MOFs constructed from metal-clusters.  These clusters are often formed in situ, whereas the linkers are generally pre-formed.  The geometry and connectivity of a linker dictate the structure of the resulting MOF.  Adjustments of linker geometry, length, ratio, and functional-group can tune the size, shape, and internal surface property of a MOF for a targeted application.  In this crit. review, the authors highlight advances in MOF synthesis focusing on linker design.  Examples of building MOFs to reach unique properties, such as unprecedented surface area, pore aperture, mol. recognition, stability, and catalysis, through linker design are described.  Further search for application-oriented MOFs through judicious selection of metal clusters and org. linkers is desirable.  In this review, linkers are categorized as ditopic (Section 1), tritopic (Section 2), tetratopic (Section 3), hexatopic (Section 4), octatopic (Section 5), mixed (Section 6), desymmetrized (Section 7), metallo (Section 8), and N-heterocyclic linkers (Section 9).
Solvent-Assisted Linker Exchange: An Alternative to the De Novo Synthesis of Unattainable Metal-Organic Frameworks
Karagiaridi, Olga; Bury, Wojciech; Mondloch, Joseph E.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.

A review.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have gained considerable attention as hybrid materials-in part because of a multitude of potential useful applications, ranging from gas sepn. to catalysis and light harvesting.  Unfortunately, de novo synthesis of MOFs with desirable function-property combinations is not always reliable and may suffer from vagaries such as formation of undesirable topologies, low soly. of precursors, and loss of functionality of the sensitive network components.  The recently discovered synthetic approach coined solvent-assisted linker exchange (SALE) constitutes a simple to implement strategy for circumventing these setbacks; its use has already gave a variety of MOF materials previously unobtainable by direct synthesis methods.  This Review provides a perspective of the achievements in MOF research that were made possible with SALE and examines the studies that have facilitated the understanding and broadened the scope of use of this invaluable synthetic tool.
Rational Design and Crystal Structure Determination of a 3-D Metal-Organic Jungle-Gym-like Open Framework
Kitaura, Ryo; Iwahori, Fumiyasu; Matsuda, Ryotaro; Kitagawa, Susumu; Kubota, Yoshiki; Takata, Masaki; Kobayashi, Tatsuo C.

A new three-dimensional (3-D) jungle-gym-like open metal-org. framework, [Cu(tfdc)(dabco)0.5] (H2tfdc = tetrafluorobenzene-1,2-dicarboxylic acid) was synthesized from the two-dimensional (2-D) layer compd. [Cu(tfdc)(MeOH)] and dabco using a heterogeneous pillar insertion reaction.  Both the starting 2-dimensional layer and the resulting 3-dimensional open compds. were characterized using x-ray crystallog.
Reversible Two-Dimensional-Three Dimensional Framework Transformation within a Prototype Metal-Organic Framework
Chen, Zhenxia; Xiang, Shengchang; Zhao, Dongyuan; Chen, Banglin

The prototype three-dimensional metal-org. framework Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)·4DMF·0.5H2O (MOF-1, BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) and two-dimensional Zn2(BDC)2(H2O)2·(DMF)2 (MOF-2) can be reversibly transformed with each other in which the activated MOF-2 exhibits high selective gas adsorption with respect to C2H2/CO2 at room temp.  Desolvated MOF-1 and MOF-2 were characterized by x-ray crystallog.
Stepwise pillar insertion into metal-organic frameworks: a sequential self-assembly approach

The authors present the sequential self-assembly of isoreticular bilayer metal-org. frameworks via a pillar insertion route.  The authors also report the construction of a 3D framework from a 2D bilayer framework in an overall three-step self-assembly.  The authors prepd. several MOFs: PPF-1 [Zn2(ZnTCPP)], PPF-4 [Zn2(ZnTCPP)(BPY)1.5], PPF-18 [Zn2(ZnTCPP)(DPNI)], PPF-21, [Zn2(ZnTCPP)(DPT)], PPF-27 [Zn2(ZnTCPP)(BPY)]; where TCPP = 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)21H,23H-porphyrin, BPY = 4,4'-bipyridine, DPNI = N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthaleneteracarboxydiimide, DPT = 3,6-di-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine.
Combinational Synthetic Approaches for Isoreticular and Polymorphic Metal-Organic Frameworks with Tuned Pore Geometries and Surface Properties
Jeong, Seok; Kim, Dongwook; Shin, Sunyoung; Moon, Dohyun; Cho, Sung June; Lah, Myoung Soo

Isoreticular and polymorphic 3D MOFs have been prepd. via the combination of direct solvothermal reactions, postsynthetic ligand exchanges of the MOFs prepd. via the direct solvothermal reactions, and postsynthetic ligand insertions into a 2D MOF.  The appropriate pore dimensions, surface areas, and adsorption enthalpies of the MOFs combined well to produce the largest working CO2 capture capacities via the pressure swing adsorption process.
Route to a Family of Robust, Non-interpenetrated Metal-Organic Frameworks with pto-like Topology
Klein, Nicole; Senkovska, Irena; Baburin, Igor A.; Gruenker, Ronny; Stoeck, Ulrich; Schlichtenmayer, Maurice; Streppel, Barbara; Mueller, Uwe; Leoni, Stefano; Hirscher, Michael; Kaskel, Stefan

A combination of topol. rules and quantum chem. calcns. has facilitated the development of a rational metal-org. framework (MOF) synthetic strategy using the tritopic benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate (btb) linker and a neutral cross-linker 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy).  New compds., [M2(bipy)]3(btb)4 (DUT-23(M), M = Zn, Co, Cu, Ni), [Cu2/Zn2(bisqui)]3(btb)4 (DUT-24, bisqui = di-Et (R,S)-4,4'-biquinoline-3,3'-dicarboxylate), [Cu2(py)1.5(H2O)0.5]3(btb)4 (DUT-33, py = pyridine), and [Cu2(H2O)2]3(btb)4 (DUT-34), with high sp. surface areas and pore vols. (up to 2.03 m3 g-1 for DUT-23(Co)) were synthesized.  For DUT-23(Co), excess storage capacities were detd. for methane (268 mg g-1 at 100 bar and 298 K), H (74 mg g-1 at 40 bar and 77 K), and n-butane (99 mg g-1at 293 K).  DUT-34 is a non cross-linked version of DUT-23 (noninterpenetrated pendant to MOF-14) that possesses open metal sites and can therefore be used as a catalyst.  The accessibility of the pores in DUT-34 to potential substrate mols. was proven by liq. phase adsorption.  By exchanging the N,N donor 4,4'-bipyridine with a substituted racemic biquinoline, DUT-24 was obtained.  This opens a route to the synthesis of a chiral compd., which could be interesting for enantioselective sepn.
Post-synthetic reversible incorporation of organic linkers into porous metal-organic frameworks through single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations and modification of gas sorption properties
Park, Hye Jeong; Cheon, Young Eun; Suh, Myunghyun Paik

Porous metal-org. framework (MOF) {[Zn2(TCPBDA)(H2O)2]·30DMF·6H2O}n (SNU-30) was prepd. by solvothermal reaction of N,N,N',N'-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)biphenyl-4,4'-diamine (H4TCPBDA) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in DMF/tBuOH.  Post-synthetic modification of SNU-30 by the insertion of 3,6-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine (bpta) afforded single-cryst. {[Zn2(TCPBDA)(bpta)]·23DMF·4H2O}n (SNU-31SC), in which channels were divided by the bpta linkers.  The bridging bpta ligand in the MOF was bent due to steric constraints.  SNU-31 was also prepd. through a one-pot solvothermal synthesis from ZnII, TCPBDA4-, and bpta.  The bpta linker could be liberated from this MOF by immersion in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) to afford the single-cryst. SNU-30SC, which is structurally similar to SNU-30.  Desolvated solid SNU-30' adsorbed N2, O2, H2, CO2, and CH4 gases, whereas desolvated SNU-31' exhibited selective adsorption of CO2 over N2, O2, H2, and CH4, thus demonstrating that the gas adsorption properties of MOF can be modified by post-synthetic insertion/removal of a bridging ligand.
Opening Metal-Organic Frameworks Vol. 2: Inserting Longer Pillars into Pillared-Paddlewheel Structures through Solvent-Assisted Linker Exchange
Karagiaridi, Olga; Bury, Wojciech; Tylianakis, Emmanuel; Sarjeant, Amy A.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.

Solvent-assisted linker exchange (SALE) was performed on a pillared-paddlewheel metal-org. framework (MOF), SALEM-5, to achieve incorporation of longer linkers into the material.  The 9-Å meso-1,2-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2-ethanediol pillar of SALEM-5 was successfully replaced by 11-Å, 14-Å, and 17-Å pillars to generate daughter MOFs SALEM-6, SALEM-7, and SALEM-8.  The daughter frameworks possess more open cages, as was demonstrated by structural modeling from the powder x-ray diffraction patterns, and larger solvent accessible space, as was demonstrated by TGA.  Finally, a study was performed to examine the effect of pKa of monoprotonated dipyridyl pillars (as an indicator of the Zn-L bond strength) on the outcome of SALE.
Dye Encapsulation Inside a New Mesoporous Metal-Organic Framework for Multifunctional Solvatochromic-Response Function
Gruenker, Ronny; Bon, Volodymyr; Heerwig, Andreas; Klein, Nicole; Mueller, Philipp; Stoeck, Ulrich; Baburin, Igor A.; Mueller, Uwe; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan

A robust mesoporous metalorg. framework (MOF) DUT-25 composed from tritopic (benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate), tetratopic (N,N,N',N'-benzidinetetrabenzoate) ligands, as well as [Zn4O]6+ secondary building unit exhibited extremely high porosity and sp. surface area (4670 m2/g), which enabled exceptionally high excess uptakes of gases, such as methane (201 mg/g at 298 K), H (69 mg/g at 77 K), CO2 (1.48 g/g at 298 K), 〈n-butane (0.97 g/g), and Kr (1.46 g/g at 298 K).  DUT-25 framework showed solvatochromic fluorescence behavior.  The encapsulation of solvatochromic dyes into the MOF is an elegant way to create a multifunctional material for visual detection and simultaneous removal of undesirable substances.  Such a composite system can be potentially useful, because it represents an adsorber with integrated optical detection, specifically for toxic solvents or vapors.  The desorption of the functional guest can be induced by pH change demonstrating the general potential of such composites for controlled release of guest mols., which is highly desirable for medical applications, such as pharmacotherapy.  Crystallog. data are given.
A Water-Stable Porphyrin-Based Metal-Organic Framework Active for Visible-Light Photocatalysis
Fateeva, Alexandra; Chater, Philip A.; Ireland, Christopher P.; Tahir, Asif A.; Khimyak, Yaroslav Z.; Wiper, Paul V.; Darwent, James R.; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.

Water-stable porous porphyrin-metal org. framework with surface area 1400 m2-g-1 is reported which performs visible-light driven H2 photogeneration from H2O.  Thus, reaction of AlCl3.6H2O with free-base tetra-(4-carbonylphenyl)porphyrin (H2TCPP) in H2O under hydrothermal conditions followed by washing with DMF produced porous red H2TCPP[AlOH]2(DMF3-(H2O)2) (Al-PMOF).  Modification of Al-PMOF by porphyrin metalation with anhyd. Zinc acetate produced purple compd. Zn-TCCP-[AlOH]2 (2).  Crystal structure and optical properties of Al-PMOF and 2 were studied.  Photocatalytic efficiency of Al-PMOF and 2 was evaluated for H2 evolution from H2O under visible light in presence of methylviologen, EDTA and Pt co-catalyst.
The Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database of, and symbols for, crystal nets
O'Keeffe, Michael; Peskov, Maxim A.; Ramsden, Stuart J.; Yaghi, Omar M.

During the past decade, interest has grown tremendously in the design and synthesis of cryst. materials constructed from mol. clusters linked by extended groups of atoms.  Most notable are metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), in which polyat. inorg. metal-contg. clusters are joined by polytopic linkers. (Although these materials are sometimes referred to as coordination polymers, we prefer to differentiate them, because MOFs are based on strong linkages that yield robust frameworks.) The realization that MOFs could be designed and synthesized in a rational way from mol. building blocks led to the emergence of a discipline that we call reticular chem.MOFs can be represented as a special kind of graph called a periodic net.  Such descriptions date back to the earliest crystallog. studies but have become much more common recently because thousands of new structures and hundreds of underlying nets have been reported.  In the simplest cases (e.g., the structure of diamond), the atoms in the crystal become the vertices of the net, and bonds are the links (edges) that connect them.  In the case of MOFs, polyat. groups act as the vertices and edges of the net.Because of the explosive growth in this area, a need has arisen for a universal system of nomenclature, classification, identification, and retrieval of these topol. structures.  We have developed a system of symbols for the identification of three periodic nets of interest, and this system is now in wide use.  In this Account, we explain the underlying methodol. of assigning symbols and describe the Reticular Chem. Structure Resource (RCSR), in which about 1600 such nets are collected and illustrated in a database that can be searched by symbol, name, keywords, and attributes.  The resource also contains searchable data for polyhedra and layers.The database entries come from systematic enumerations or from known chem. compds. or both.  In the latter case, refs. to occurrences are provided.  We describe some crystallog., topol., and other attributes of nets and explain how they are reported in the database.  We also describe how the database can be used as a tool for the design and structural anal. of new materials.  Assocd. with each net is a natural tiling, which is a natural partition of space into space-filling tiles.  The database allows export of data that can be used to analyze and illustrate such tilings.
Acta Crystallographica, Section D: Biological Crystallography

A review.  Automated structure validation was introduced in chem. crystallog. about 12 years ago as a tool to assist practitioners with the exponential growth in crystal structure analyses.  Validation has since evolved into an easy-to-use checkCIF/PLATON web-based IUCr service.  The result of a crystal structure detn. has to be supplied as a CIF-formatted computer-readable file.  The checking software tests the data in the CIF for completeness, quality, and consistency.  In addn., the reported structure is checked for incomplete anal., errors in the anal., and relevant issues to be verified.  A validation report is generated in the form of a list of ALERTS on the issues to be cor., checked, or commented on.  Structure validation has largely eliminated obvious problems with structure reports published in IUCr journals, such as refinement in a space group of too low symmetry.  This paper reports on the current status of structure validation and possible future extensions.
Computational structure characterisation tools in application to ordered and disordered porous materials

A review.  In this article, we present a set of computational tools for systematic characterization of ordered and disordered porous materials.  These tools include calcn. of the accessible surface area and geometric pore size distribution, anal. of the structure connectivity and percolation anal. of the porous space.  We briefly discuss the algorithms behind these calcns.  To demonstrate the capabilities of the tools and the type of insights that can be gained from their application, we consider a series of case studies.  These case studies include small mol. fragments, several cryst. metal-org. materials, and variants of these materials with induced defects and disorder in their structure.  The simulation package is available upon request.
Local Structure of Framework Cu(II) in HKUST-1 Metallorganic Framework: Spectroscopic Characterization upon Activation and Interaction with Adsorbates
Prestipino, C.; Regli, L.; Vitillo, J. G.; Bonino, F.; Damin, A.; Lamberti, C.; Zecchina, A.; Solari, P. L.; Kongshaug, K. O.; Bordiga, S.

XRD, UV-Vis, EXAFS, XANES, and Raman techniques have been used to study the removal of water mols. coordinated to the Cu(II) framework atoms of the novel HKUST-1 metal-org. framework.  The dehydration process preserves the cryst. nature of the material, just causing a redn. of the cell vol. due to the shrinking of the [Cu2C4O8] cage.  The removal of adsorbed H2O mol. makes the framework Cu(II) sites available for interaction with other probe mols.  In situ IR spectroscopy has evidenced the formation at liq. nitrogen temp. of labile Cu(II)···CO adducts characterized by a ~ν(C-O) = 2178 cm-1 and at 15 K of Cu(II)···H2 adducts characterized by a ~ν(H-H) = 4100 cm-1.  To the best of our knowledge, we have obsd. for the first time a clear signal of Cu(II) carbonyl and dihydrogen complexes formed inside a cryst. microporous hosting matrix.  The sinking of the oxygens of the carboxyl units, undergone by the Cu(II) framework ions in the dehydration process, is responsible for the rather low coordinative unsatn. of Cu(II).  The important shielding effect of the four oxygen framework atoms is testified by the low polarization factor of the Cu(II) site probed by both CO and H2 mols.
There is no corresponding record for this reference.
